Dominion Affairs and of a Dominions Office,the practical aspects of the case shouldbe met by continuing the new Secretary-ship in the same person as the ColonialSecretaryship and by retaining the dominions office for internal administration purposes has a part of the Colonial Office:(ii) That an additional Parliamentary Under-Seoretary of State should be appointedto deal with Dominion affairs and to actas Chairman of the Oversea SettlementCommittee:(iii) That an additional Permanent Under-Seoretaxy should be appointed so as toenable each side of the work to be directly in charge of a man of first-class ability and of the right temperament:(Iv) The control of the Colonial Office as an office to be vested in. the Permanent Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies.After considerable discussion, the cabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary of State for the colonies should see the High Commissioners of theDominions and should inform them that theGovernment approved in principle the follow -ing changes in the organisation of theColonial Office and would be glad if theHigh Commissioners would communicate theminformally to their respective governments and ascertain whether they would meet with approval:-(l) That a separate Secretaryship of Statefor Dominion or Imperial Aifairs shouldbe created and should be held by thesame person as the Secretaryship ofState for the Colonies:(2) That, having regard to the importanceof Oversea Settlement and to the desir-ability of rendering possible personalvisits to the various parts of theEmpire by the Secretary of State forthe Colonies and other representativesof the Colonial Office, an additionalTHS DOMINIONSAND THECOLONIALOFFICE. After hearing from the Secretary of State for.India, as Chairman of the Naval Programme Committee,previous reference: a verbal report of the present position on that cabinet 8[(25), Con- Committee, the Cabinet agreed elusion 1.) in the first instancei* To approve the reference/ to theCommittee of Imperial Defence of the"following questions:-(a) The policy of leaving to the admiralty the responsibility for the Naval defenceof the Empire on the basis of the one-Power standard was last reaffirmed bythe Committee of Lmoerial Defence in1923.Is it proposed to reverse or modifythis decision?If not, what does it in practiceinvolve? In what waters are we to beas strong as any other Power? Do wesatisfy the requirements of a one-Powerstandard if our fleet wherever situateis equal to the fleet of any other nationwherever situate?(b) Is aggressive action on the part of Japan,such as would tend to involve this countryin armed conflict in the Pacific duringthe next ten years, a contingency so seriously to be apprehended as to'impose upon the Admiralty the responsibility ofmaking material preparations to meet it,upon the basis that we must in the Pacificbe able to confront and defeat their wholemaritime strength?(c) If the decision referred to in question (a)still stands, ought the British war plan to contemplate placing at Singapore fora decisive battle in the Pacific a Britishbattle fleet with cruisers, flotillas andall ancillary vessels'superior in strength,or at least equal, to the sea-going Navyof Japan0 If so, on what date couldthis, or ought it to, be achieved having' regard to the strength which must beretained in Home Waters'''(d) In the event of war occurring before the base at Singapore is capable"of sustaininga British fleet superior to the -JapaneseNavy, what ought the interim British warplan to be?(e) If the answers to (b) and (c) are in the negative, what should be the guidingprinciples on which to form a"war plan,with particular reference to the develop-ment of the base and the maintenance of fuel and other reserves in the Singaporearea? (f) If, on the other hand, the answer to (b) is in the affirmative, andto (o) in the negative, on whatprinciples should' the British Warplan be based?That the decision on the above questions should be reserved entirely for theCabinet, with whom the ultimate responsi-bility could alone lie, to whom shouldbe communicated not only the recommenda-tions but also the Minutes of the Com-mittee of Imperial Defence on the subject,and any other Papers necessary to setforth the views of the Chiefs of Staffof the three Services. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theFirst Lord of the Admiralty, enclosing a letter from tieAdmiralty to the Treasury on the subject of the arrange-ruents proposed for the construction of an extensionalsection of the floating dock at Singapore (Paper O.P.-156 (2,5)).The Cabinet -were reminded that when the questionof the extension of the l%val Base at Singapore hadbeen under consideration by a Sub-Committee of theCommittee of Imperial Defence, no mention had beenmade of the necessity for additional expenditure on theextension of the floating dock, and that the MarquessCurzon, who had been Chairman of the Sub-Committee, in announcing the total expenditure to be incurred on theNaval Base at Singapore during the next few years had not Included the cost of the extension of the floating dock. To introduce a Supplementary Estimateinvolving additional expenditure over and above thatannounced by Lord Curzon, but nevertheless requiredin connection with the Singapore base, would excitemuch adverse comment. It was further pointed out thatthe question of the extension of the floating dock waspart of the general question of Ifeval construction which had been referred to the Cabinet Naval programme committee, and it was suggested that the Cabinet^decision in regard to the floating dock should be reserved until after they had received and dealt with gReport of the committee of Imperial Defence on the questionnaire referred to in the previous Conclusion.On the other hand, it was urged that theprogramme submitted by the Sub-Committee of theCommittee of Imperial Defence. and approved by theCabinet for placing a floating dook at Singapore by the' Spring of 1928 could not be carried out unlessthe oonstruction work on the extension of the dock wasbegan in July next, and that this would not be possible if the decision in the matter was delayed until afterthe large questions of Naval Policy referred to in theprevious Conclusion had been examined by the Committeeof Imperial Defence arid decided by the Cabinet.The Cabinet agreed - That the Naval Programme Committeeshould invest!gate "whether in facta postponement for a few months ofa decision was likely seriously to delay the completion of the programme approved by the Cabinet for stationingthe floating dock at Singapore bythe end of the financial"year 1927-28,and in the event of their finding thatserious delay must result from post-postponing the decision, but only in this event," they should make a separate report to the Cabinet as to the desir-ability of incurring the expenditureproposed by the Admiralty.
